     7â†’## Overview
     8â†’
     9â†’TempDD is a template-driven development framework that enables structured human-AI collaboration through customizable workflows and agent-guided template interactions. 
    10â†’
    11â†’As project complexity increases, AI Agents face challenges operating independently, making human-in-the-loop collaboration increasingly critical. Developers need effective tools to communicate with these black-box AI Agents. Template-driven approaches provide structured communication, reduce cognitive load, and enable consistent AI collaboration through guided workflows. This repository provides a framework that allows users to customize workflows according to their development projects, simplifying the process into a series of template-filling tasks. The framework incorporates agent mechanisms to reduce template complexity, enabling AI Agents to effectively assist users in completing documentation. We envision this framework being applicable across various development scenarios and even non-development contexts, while fostering open-source collaboration to integrate global knowledge.
    12â†’
    13â†’## Features
    14â†’
    15â†’- ğŸ“š **Progressive AI mastery through layered docs** - Transform from AI user to AI master with sophisticated multi-layer  documentation that amplifies your control over AI behavior
    16â†’- ğŸ“‹ **Customizable template-driven workflow** - Structured approach to project development with customizable templates
    17â†’- ğŸ’¬ **Customizable agent-guided template interaction** - Customizable agents adapt to each template, providing interactive guidance to help users fill templates collaboratively
    18â†’- ğŸ¤– **Cross-AI tool integration** - Seamless integration with Claude Code, Gemini CLI, Cursor, and GitHub Copilot
    19â†’- ğŸŒ **Multi-language support** - Users can fill templates using their preferred language
    20â†’
    21â†’## Quick Start
    22â†’
    23â†’### 1. Installation
    24â†’
    25â†’Install `tempdd` using uv:
    26â†’
    27â†’```bash
    28â†’uv tool install --force --from git+https://github.com/GitYCC/TempDD.git tempdd && exec $SHELL
    29â†’```
    30â†’
    31â†’### 2. Initialize Project
    32â†’
    33â†’Create a new project directory and initialize TempDD:
    34â†’
    35â†’```bash
    36â†’mkdir demo
    37â†’cd demo
    38â†’tempdd init  # You can choose the built-in workflow and preferred AI tool during initialization
    39â†’```
    40â†’
    41â†’### 3. Example: Default Workflow with Claude Code
    42â†’
    43â†’The following example demonstrates using the default workflow with Claude Code. For detailed customization options and available workflows, refer to `tempdd help`.
    44â†’
    45â†’Once you enter Claude Code, execute the following commands in sequence:
    46â†’
    47â†’```bash
    48â†’# Get help and understand available commands
    49â†’/tempdd-go help
    50â†’
    51â†’# Generate product requirements document
    52â†’/tempdd-go prd build
    53â†’
    54â†’# After finishing the PRD, create architecture design
    55â†’/tempdd-go arch build
    56â†’
    57â†’# After finishing the architecture design document, conduct research
    58â†’/tempdd-go research build
    59â†’
    60â†’# After finishing the research report, build implementation blueprint
    61â†’/tempdd-go blueprint build
    62â†’
    63â†’# After finishing the blueprint, generate task list
    64â†’/tempdd-go tasks build
    65â†’
    66â†’# After finishing the task list, execute tasks to generate the codes
    67â†’/tempdd-go tasks run
    68â†’```
    69â†’
    70â†’From this example, you can see that development progresses from idea to implementation through multi-layered documentation. Each document is filled out by AI asking users for input when needed, which reduces the complexity of form-filling for users while enhancing consensus between AI and humans. Worth noting, the research step involves AI proactively searching for information online to improve its understanding of the implementation. I believe better workflows exist, and we shouldn't expect one workflow to satisfy every project. Therefore, this framework is designed to be easily customizable. Please refer to section ["Customize your workflow"](#customize-your-workflow) to learn more.
    71â†’
    72â†’
    73â†’## Customize your workflow
    74â†’
    75â†’TempDD allows you to create custom workflows tailored to your specific development needs. The framework's template-driven architecture makes customization straightforwardâ€”just define your stages in YAML and create corresponding templates.
    76â†’
    77â†’Follow the below steps to customize your workflow:
    78â†’1. **Understand the design**: Read [Operating Principles](docs/operating-principles.md) to learn how template-driven architecture enables easy customization
    79â†’2. **Read the guide**: See [./customized/](./customized/) for comprehensive workflow creation instructions
    80â†’3. **Create your workflow** following the structure and examples provided
    81â†’4. **Initialize project** with your custom workflow:
    82â†’
    83â†’```bash
    84â†’tempdd init --workflow /path/to/your/custom/workflow_dir/
    85â†’```
    86â†’
    87â†’## Contributing Built-in Workflows
    88â†’
    89â†’We encourage contributors to help expand TempDD's built-in workflow collection! By contributing new workflows, you can help other developers benefit from proven development patterns and specialized domain workflows.
    90â†’
    91â†’### How to Contribute a New Built-in Workflow
    92â†’
    93â†’1. **Fork this repository** - Create your own fork to work on
    94â†’2. **Add your workflow files**:

    99â†’Your contributions will help make TempDD more valuable for developers across different domains and use cases. Whether it's a workflow for mobile development, data science, DevOps, or any other specialization, we welcome your expertise!

    10â†’---
    11â†’
    12â†’## Core Concepts
    13â†’
    14â†’### What is TempDD?
    15â†’
    16â†’TempDD (Template-Driven Development) is a framework that **structures the development process** through three core mechanisms:
    17â†’
    18â†’```
    19â†’ğŸ“‹ Configuration File (config.yaml)
    20â†’   â†“ Defines workflow
    21â†’ğŸ“ Template Files (templates/*.md)
    22â†’   â†“ Defines structure and AI behavior for each stage
    23â†’ğŸ¤– AI Collaboration
    24â†’   â†“ Assists in completing documents through guided conversation
    25â†’```
    26â†’
    27â†’### Design Philosophy
    28â†’
    29â†’TempDD follows a simple philosophy:
    30â†’
    31â†’> **"Users only need to declare what they want, the system automatically handles how to do it"**
    32â†’
    33â†’This means:
    34â†’- âœ… Users define workflow in YAML â†’ System executes automatically
    35â†’- âœ… Users define AI behavior in templates â†’ AI follows automatically
    36â†’- âœ… Users add stages or modify flow â†’ No code changes needed
    37â†’
    38â†’---
    39â†’
    40â†’## How the System Works
    41â†’
    42â†’### Overall Architecture
    43â†’
    44â†’```
    45â†’                    User
    46â†’                      â”‚
    47â†’                      â”‚ Execute command: /tempdd-go prd build
    48â†’                      â†“
    49â†’              â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
    50â†’              â”‚    AI Tool      â”‚  (Claude/Gemini/Cursor/Copilot)
    51â†’              â”‚ Command System  â”‚
    52â†’              â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
    53â†’                       â”‚ Call: tempdd ai "prd build"
    54â†’                       â†“
    55â†’              â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
    56â†’              â”‚  TempDD Core    â”‚
    57â†’              â”‚                 â”‚
    58â†’              â”‚ 1. Read config  â”‚  config.yaml
    59â†’              â”‚ 2. Load templateâ”‚  templates/prd.md
    60â†’              â”‚ 3. Generate     â”‚  [AI_INSTRUCTION_START]...
    61â†’              â”‚    instruction  â”‚
    62â†’              â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
    63â†’                       â”‚ Return AI instruction
    64â†’                       â†“
    65â†’              â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
    66â†’              â”‚  AI Execution   â”‚
    67â†’              â”‚                 â”‚
    68â†’              â”‚ - Converse with â”‚
    69â†’              â”‚   user          â”‚

    71â†’              â”‚ - Complete stageâ”‚
    72â†’              â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

    75â†’### Execution Flow Example
    76â†’
    77â†’Suppose the user executes `/tempdd-go prd build`:
    78â†’
    79â†’```
    80â†’Step 1: Read configuration
    81â†’   config.yaml â†’ stages: [prd, arch, blueprint]
    82â†’   define.prd â†’ template: templates/prd.md
    83â†’
    84â†’Step 2: Parse template
    85â†’   templates/prd.md â†’
    86â†’   â”œâ”€ YAML frontmatter: build.prompt (AI behavior definition)
    87â†’   â””â”€ Markdown content: document structure
    88â†’
    89â†’Step 3: Handle dependencies
    90â†’   prd stage's input_symbols: null (no dependencies)
    91â†’   prd stage's output_symbol: PATH_PRD (output path)
    92â†’
    93â†’Step 4: Replace variables
    94â†’   {{TARGET_DOCUMENT}} â†’ docs-for-works/001_initialization/prd.md
    95â†’
    96â†’Step 5: Generate AI instruction
    97â†’   [AI_INSTRUCTION_START]
    98â†’   System rules (language settings, etc.)
    99â†’   ===
   100â†’   Stage instruction (with variables processed)
   101â†’   [AI_INSTRUCTION_END]
   102â†’
   103â†’Step 6: AI execution

   105â†’```
   106â†’
   107â†’### Connecting Stages
   108â†’
   109â†’TempDD uses a **Symbol System** to connect different stages:
   110â†’
   111â†’```
   112â†’Stage 1: PRD
   113â†’   Input: None
   114â†’   Output: PATH_PRD â†’ "docs-for-works/001_initialization/prd.md"
   115â†’
   116â†’Stage 2: Architecture
   117â†’   Input: PATH_PRD (reads PRD content)
   118â†’   Output: PATH_ARCH â†’ "docs-for-works/001_initialization/arch.md"
   119â†’
   120â†’Stage 3: Blueprint
   121â†’   Input: PATH_PRD, PATH_ARCH (reads content from previous two stages)
   122â†’   Output: PATH_BLUEPRINT â†’ "docs-for-works/001_initialization/blueprint.md"
   123â†’```
   124â†’
   125â†’**Key Mechanism**:
   126â†’- Each stage's output document path is stored as a symbol (e.g., `PATH_PRD`)
   127â†’- Subsequent stages can reference it in templates using `{{PATH_PRD}}`
   128â†’- System automatically replaces it with the actual path

   132â†’## Template-Driven Implementation
   133â†’
   134â†’### What is Template-Driven?
   135â†’
   136â†’**Core Concept**: Separation of "process" and "content"
   137â†’
   138â†’```
   139â†’Traditional Approach:
   140â†’   Code + Logic + Content â†’ Mixed together, hard to modify
   141â†’
   142â†’Template-Driven:
   143â†’   Configuration (process definition) â†’ config.yaml
   144â†’   Templates (content structure) â†’ templates/*.md
   145â†’   Execution (automation) â†’ TempDD Core
   146â†’```
   147â†’
   148â†’### TempDD Template Structure
   149â†’
   150â†’Each template file contains a **two-layer design**:
   151â†’
   152â†’```markdown
   153â†’---
   154â†’# Layer 1: YAML Frontmatter (defines AI behavior)
   155â†’build:
   156â†’  prompt: |
   157â†’    You are a Product Manager...
   158â†’    Target document: {{TARGET_DOCUMENT}}
   159â†’
   160â†’    Your workflow:
   161â†’    1. Ask user what they want to build
   162â†’    2. Systematically collect requirements
   163â†’    3. Fill out complete PRD document
   164â†’
   165â†’run:
   166â†’  prompt: |
   167â†’    Instructions for execution...
   168â†’---
   169â†’
   170â†’# Layer 2: Markdown Content (defines document structure)
   171â†’
   172â†’# Product Requirements Document
   173â†’
   174â†’## Basic Information
   175â†’**Product Name**: [[To be filled]]
   176â†’
   177â†’## Goals & Objectives
   178â†’[[To be filled]]
   179â†’
   180â†’## User Scenarios
   181â†’[[To be filled]]
   182â†’```
   183â†’
   184â†’**Design Insight**:
   185â†’- **Layer 1** controls **how AI interacts with users**
   186â†’- **Layer 2** controls **the final document structure**
   187â†’
   188â†’### Configuration-Driven Execution
   189â†’
   190â†’All workflow is defined by `config.yaml`:
   191â†’
   192â†’```yaml
   193â†’# Declare what stages exist
   194â†’stages:
   195â†’  - prd
   196â†’  - arch
   197â†’  - blueprint
   198â†’
   199â†’# Define each stage's details
   200â†’define:
   201â†’  prd:
   202â†’    template: templates/prd.md     # Which template to use
   203â†’    input_symbols: null            # What inputs are needed (none)
   204â†’    output_symbol: PATH_PRD        # What to output (PRD path)
   205â†’
   206â†’  arch:
   207â†’    template: templates/arch.md
   208â†’    input_symbols: [PATH_PRD]      # Needs PRD as input
   209â†’    output_symbol: PATH_ARCH
   210â†’

Interact with Language Server Protocol (LSP) servers to get code intelligence features.

Supported operations:
- goToDefinition: Find where a symbol is defined
- findReferences: Find all references to a symbol
- hover: Get hover information (documentation, type info) for a symbol
- documentSymbol: Get all symbols (functions, classes, variables) in a document
- workspaceSymbol: Search for symbols across the entire workspace
- goToImplementation: Find implementations of an interface or abstract method
- prepareCallHierarchy: Get call hierarchy item at a position (functions/methods)
- incomingCalls: Find all functions/methods that call the function at a position
- outgoingCalls: Find all functions/methods called by the function at a position

All operations require:
- filePath: The file to operate on
- line: The line number (1-based, as shown in editors)
- character: The character offset (1-based, as shown in editors)

Note: LSP servers must be configured for the file type. If no server is available, an error will be returned.
